books.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:1
verses.text: ) there worshipped, and thence was called Soroapis, and afterwards Serapis by the custom of the natives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:2
verses.text: And Apis is third after Inachus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:3
verses.text: Further, Latona lived in the time of Tityus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:4
verses.text: "For he dragged Latona, the radiant consort of Zeus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:5
verses.text: Now Tityus was contemporary with Tantalus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:6
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, the Boeotian Pindar writes, "And in time was Apollo born;" and no wonder when he is found along with Hercules, serving Admetus "for a long year".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:7
verses.text: Zethus and Amphion, the inventors of music, lived about the age of Cadmus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:8
verses.text: And should one assert that Phemonoe was the first who sang oracles in verse to Acrisius, let him know that twenty-seven years after Phemonoe, lived Orpheus, and Musaeus, and Linus the teacher of Hercules.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:9
verses.text: And Homer and Hesiod are much more recent than the Trojan war; and after them the legislators among the Greeks are far more recent, Lycurgus and Solon, and the seven wise men, and Pherecydes of Syros, and Pythagoras the great, who lived later, about the Olympiads, as we have shown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:10
verses.text: We have also demonstrated Moses to be more ancient, not only than those called poets and wise men among the Greeks, but than the most of their deities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:11
verses.text: Nor he alone, but the Sibyl also is more ancient than Orpheus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:12
verses.text: For it is said, that respecting her appellation and her oracular utterances there are several accounts; that being a Phrygian, she was called Artemis; and that on her arrival at Delphi, she sang—  "O Delphians, ministers of far-darting Apollo, I come to declare the mind of aegis-bearing Zeus, Enraged as I am at my own brother Apollo".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:13
verses.text: There is another also, an Erythraean, called Herophile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:14
verses.text: These are mentioned by Heraclides of Pontus in his work On Oracles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:15
verses.text: I pass over the Egyptian Sibyl, and the Italian, who inhabited the Carmentale in Rome, whose son was Evander, who built the temple of Pan in Rome, called the Lupercal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:16
verses.text: It is worth our while, having reached this point, to examine the dates of the other prophets among the Hebrews who succeeded Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:17
verses.text: After the close of Moses's life, Joshua succeeded to the leadership of the people, and he, after warring for sixty-five years, rested in the good land other five-and-twenty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:18
verses.text: As the book of Joshua relates, the above mentioned man was the successor of Moses twenty-seven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:19
verses.text: Then the Hebrews having sinned, were delivered to Chusachar king of Mesopotamia for eight years, as the book of Judges mentions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:20
verses.text: But  having afterwards besought the Lord, they receive for leader Gothoniel, the younger brother of Caleb, of the tribe of Judah, who, having slain the king of Mesopotamia, ruled over the people forty years in succession.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:21
verses.text: And having again sinned, they were delivered into the hands of aeglom king of the Moabites for eighteen years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:22
verses.text: But on their repentance, Aod, a man who had equal use of both hands, of the tribe of Ephraim, was their leader for eighty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:23
verses.text: It was he that despatched aeglom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:24
verses.text: On the death of Aod, and on their sinning again, they were delivered into the hand of Jabim king of Canaan twenty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:25
verses.text: After him Deborah the wife of Lapidoth, of the tribe of Ephraim, prophesied; and Ozias the son of Rhiesu was high priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:26
verses.text: At her instance Barak the son of Bener, of the tribe of Naphtali, commanding the army, having joined battle with Sisera, Jabim's commander-in-chief, conquered him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:27
verses.text: And after that Deborah ruled, judging the people forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:28
verses.text: On her death, the people having again sinned, were delivered into the hands of the Midianites seven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:29
verses.text: After these events, Gideon, of the tribe of Manasseh, the son of Joas, having fought with his three hundred men, and killed a hundred and twenty thousand, ruled forty years; after whom the son of Ahimelech, three years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:30
verses.text: He was succeeded by Boleas, the son of Bedan, the son of Charran, of the tribe of Ephraim, who ruled twenty-three years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:31
verses.text: After whom, the people having sinned again, were delivered to the Ammonites eighteen years; and on their repentance were commanded by Jephtha the Gileadite, of the tribe of Manasseh; and he ruled six years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:32
verses.text: After whom, Abatthan of Bethlehem, of the tribe of Juda, ruled seven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:33
verses.text: Then Ebron the Zebulonite, eight years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:34
verses.text: Then Eglom of Ephraim, eight years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:35
verses.text: Some add to the seven years of Abatthan the eight of Ebrom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:36
verses.text: And after him, the people having again transgressed, came under the power of the foreigners, the Philistines, for forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:37
verses.text: But on their returning to God, they were led by Samson, of the tribe of Dan, who conquered the foreigners in battle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:38
verses.text: He ruled twenty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:39
verses.text: And after him, there being no governor, Eli the priest judged the people for forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:40
verses.text: He was succeeded by Samuel the prophet; contemporaneously with whom Saul reigned, who held sway for twenty-seven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:41
verses.text: He anointed David.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:42
verses.text: Samuel died two years before Saul, while Abimelech was high priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:43
verses.text: He anointed Saul as king, who was the first that bore regal sway over Israel after the judges; the whole duration of whom, down to Saul, was four hundred and sixty-three years and seven months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:44
verses.text: Then in the first book of Kings there are twenty years of Saul, during which he reigned after he was renovated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:45
verses.text: And after the death of Saul, David the son of Jesse, of the tribe of Judah, reigned next in Hebron, forty years, as is contained in the second book of Kings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:46
verses.text: And Abiathar the son of Abimelech, of the kindred of Eli, was high priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:47
verses.text: In his time Gad and Nathan prophesied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:48
verses.text: From Joshua the son of Nun, then, till David received the kingdom, there intervene, according to some, four hundred and fifty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:49
verses.text: But, as the chronology set forth shows, five hundred and twenty-three years and seven months are comprehended till the death of David.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:50
verses.text: And after this Solomon the son of David reigned forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:51
verses.text: Under him Nathan continued to prophesy, who also exhorted him respecting the building of the temple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:52
verses.text: Achias of Shilo also prophesied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:53
verses.text: And both the kings, David and Solomon, were prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:54
verses.text: And Sadoc the high priest was the first who ministered in the temple which Solomon built, being the eighth from Aaron, the first high priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:55
verses.text: From Moses, then, to the age of Solomon, as some say, are five hundred and ninety-five years, and as others, five hundred and seventy-six.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:56
verses.text: And if you count, along with the four hundred and fifty years from Joshua to David, the forty years of the rule of Moses, and the other eighty years of Moses's life previous to the exodus of the Hebrews from Egypt, you will make up the sum in all of six hundred and ten years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:57
verses.text: But our chronology will run more correctly, if to the five hundred and twenty-three years and seven months till the death of David, you add the hundred and twenty years of Moses and the forty years of Solomon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:58
verses.text: For you will make up in all, down to the death of Solomon, six hundred and eighty-three years and seven months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:59
verses.text: Hiram gave his daughter to Solomon about the time of the arrival of Menelaus in Phoenicia, after the capture of Troy, as is said by Menander of Pergamus, and Laetus in The Phoenicia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:60
verses.text: And after Solomon, Roboam his son reigned for seventeen years; and Abimelech the son of Sadoc was high priest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:61
verses.text: In his reign, the kingdom being divided, Jeroboam, of the tribe of Ephraim, the servant of Solomon, reigned in Samaria; and Achias the Shilonite continued to prophesy; also Samaeas the son of Amame, and he who came from Judah to Jeroboam, and prophesied against the altar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:62
verses.text: After him his son  Abijam, twenty-three years; and likewise his son Asaman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:63
verses.text: The last, in his old age, was diseased in his feet; and in his reign prophesied Jehu the son of Ananias.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:64
verses.text: After him Jehosaphat his son reigned twenty-five years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:65
verses.text: In his reign prophesied Elias the Thesbite, and Michaeas the son of Jebla, and Abdias the son of Ananias.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:66
verses.text: And in the time of Michaeas there was also the false prophet Zedekias, the son of Chonaan.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:67
verses.text: These were followed by the reign of Joram the son of Jehosaphat, for eight years; during whose time prophesied Elias; and after Elias, Elisaeus the son of Saphat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:68
verses.text: In his reign the people in Samaria ate doves' dung and their own children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:69
verses.text: The period of Jehosaphat extends from the close of the third book of Kings to the fourth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:70
verses.text: And in the reign of Joram, Elias was translated, and Elisaeus the son of Saphat commenced prophesying, and prophesied for six years, being forty years old.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:71
verses.text: Then Ochozias reigned a year.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:72
verses.text: In his time Elisaeus continued to prophesy, and along with him Adadonaeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:73
verses.text: After him the mother of Ozias, Gotholia, reigned eight years, having slain the children of her brother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:74
verses.text: For she was of the family of Ahab.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:75
verses.text: But the sister of Ozias, Josabaea, stole Joas the son of Ozias, and invested him afterwards with the kingdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:76
verses.text: And in the time of this Gotholia, Elisaeus was still prophesying.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:77
verses.text: And after her reigned, as I said before, Joash, rescued by Josabaea the wife of Jodae the high priest, and lived in all forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:78
verses.text: There are comprised, then, from Solomon to the death of Elisaeus the prophet, as some say, one hundred and five years; according to others, one hundred and two; and, as the chronology before us shows, from the reign of Solomon an hundred and eighty-one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:79
verses.text: Now from the Trojan war to the birth of Homer, according to Philochorus, a hundred and eighty years elapsed; and he was posterior to the Ionic migration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:80
verses.text: But Aristarchus, in the Archilochian Memoirs, says that he lived during the Ionic migration, which took place a hundred and twenty years after the siege of Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:81
verses.text: But Apollodorus alleges it was an hundred and twenty years after the Ionic migration, while Agesilaus son of Doryssaeus was king of the Lacedaemonians: so that he brings Lycurgus the legislator, while still a young man, near him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:82
verses.text: Euthymenes, in the Chronicles, says that he flourished contemporaneously with Hesiod, in the time of Acastus, and was born in Chios about the four hundredth year after the capture of Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:83
verses.text: And Archimachus, in the third book of his Euboean History, is of this opinion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:84
verses.text: So that both he and Hesiod were later than Elisaeus, the prophet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:85
verses.text: And if you choose to follow the grammarian Crates, and say that Homer was born about the time of the expedition of the Heraclidae, eighty years after the taking of Troy, he will be found to be later again than Solomon, in whose days occurred the arrival of Menelaus in Phoenicia, as was said above.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:86
verses.text: Eratosthenes says that Homer's age was two hundred years after the capture of Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:87
verses.text: Further, Theopompus, in the forty-third book of the Philippics, relates that Homer was born five hundred years after the war at Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:88
verses.text: And Euphorion, in his book about the Aleuades, maintains that he was born in the time of Gyges, who began to reign in the eighteenth Olympiad, who, also he says, was the first that was called tyrant (τύραννος).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:89
verses.text: Sosibius Lacon, again, in his Record of Dates, brings Homer down to the eighth year of the reign of Charillus the son of Polydectus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:90
verses.text: Charillus reigned for sixty-four years, after whom the son of Nicander reigned thirty-nine years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:91
verses.text: In his thirty-fourth year it is said that the first Olympiad was instituted; so that Homer was ninety years before the introduction of the Olympic games.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:92
verses.text: After Joas, Amasias his son reigned as his successor thirty-nine years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:93
verses.text: He in like manner was succeeded by his son Ozias, who reigned for fifty-two years, and died a leper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:94
verses.text: And in his time prophesied Amos, and Isaiah his son, and Hosea the son of Beeri, and Jonas the son of Amathi, who was of Geth-chober, who preached to the Ninevites, and passed through the whale's belly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:95
verses.text: Then Jonathan the son of Ozias reigned for sixteen years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:96
verses.text: In his time Esaias still prophesied, and Hosea, and Michaeas the Morasthite, and Joel the son of Bethuel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:97
verses.text: Next in succession was his son Ahaz, who reigned for sixteen years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:98
verses.text: In his time, in the fifteenth year, Israel was carried away to Babylon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:99
verses.text: And Salmanasar the king of the Assyrians carried away the people of Samaria into the country of the Medes and to Babylon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:100
verses.text: Again Ahaz was succeeded by Osee, who reigned for eight years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:101
verses.text: Then followed Hezekiah, for twenty-nine years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:102
verses.text: For his sanctity, when he had approached his end, God, by Isaiah, allowed him to live for other fifteen years, giving as a sign the going back of the sun.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:103
verses.text: Up to his times Esaias, Hosea, and Micah continued prophesying.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:104
verses.text: And these are said to have lived after the age  of Lycurgus, the legislator of the Lacedaemonians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:105
verses.text: For Dieuchidas, in the fourth book of the Megarics, places the era of Lycurgus about the two hundred and ninetieth year after the capture of Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:106
verses.text: After Hezekiah, his son Manasses reigned for fifty-five years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:107
verses.text: Then his son Amos for two years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:108
verses.text: After him reigned his son Josias, distinguished for his observance of the law, for thirty-one years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:109
verses.text: He "laid the carcases of men upon the carcases of the idols," as is written in the book of Leviticus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:110
verses.text: In his reign, in the eighteenth year, the passover was celebrated, not having been kept from the days of Samuel in the intervening period.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:111
verses.text: Then Chelkias the priest, the father of the prophet Jeremiah, having fallen in with the book of the law, that had been laid up in the temple, read it and died.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:112
verses.text: And in his days Olda prohesied, and Sophonias, and Jeremiah.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:113
verses.text: And in the days of Jeremiah was Ananias the son of Azor, the false prophet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:114
verses.text: He having disobeyed Jeremiah the prophet, was slain by Pharaoh Necho king of Egypt at the river Euphrates, having encountered the latter, who was marching on the Assyrians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:115
verses.text: Josiah was succeeded by Jechoniah, called also Joachas, his son, who reigned three months and ten days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:116
verses.text: Necho king of Egypt bound him and led him to Egypt, after making his brother Joachim king in his stead, who continued his tributary for eleven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:117
verses.text: After him his namesake Joakim reigned for three months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:118
verses.text: Then Zedekiah reigned for eleven years; and up to his time Jeremiah continued to prophesy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:119
verses.text: Along with him Ezekiel the son of Buzi, and Urias the son of Samaeus, and Ambacum prophesied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:120
verses.text: Here end the Hebrew kings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:121
verses.text: There are then from the birth of Moses till this captivity nine hundred and seventy-two years; but according to strict chronological accuracy, one thousand and eighty-five, six months, ten days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:122
verses.text: From the reign of David to the captivity by the Chaldeans, four hundred and fifty-two years and six months; but as the accuracy we have observed in reference to dates makes out, four hundred and eighty-two and six months ten days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:123
verses.text: And in the twelfth year of the reign of Zedekiah, forty years before the supremacy of the Persians, Nebuchodonosor made war against the Phoenicians and the Jews, as Berosus asserts in his Chaldaean Histories.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:124
verses.text: And Joabas, writing about the Assyrians, acknowledges that he had received the history from Berosus, and testifies to his accuracy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:125
verses.text: Nebuchodonosor, therefore, having put out the eyes of Zedekiah, took him away to Babylon, and transported the whole people (the captivity lasted seventy years), with the exception of a few who fled to Egypt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:126
verses.text: Jeremiah and Ambacum were still prophesying in the time of Zedekiah.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:127
verses.text: In the fifth year of his reign Ezekiel prophesied at Babylon; after him Nahum, then Daniel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:128
verses.text: After him, again, Haggai and Zechariah prophesied in the time of Darius the First for two years; and then the angel among the twelve.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:129
verses.text: After Haggai and Zechariah, Nehemiah, the chief cup-bearer of Artaxerxes, the son of Acheli the Israelite, built the city of Jerusalem and restored the temple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:130
verses.text: During the captivity lived Esther and Mordecai, whose book is still extant, as also that of the Maccabees.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:131
verses.text: During this captivity Mishael, Ananias, and Azarias, refusing to worship the image, and being thrown into a furnace of fire, were saved by the appearance of an angel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:132
verses.text: At that time, on account of the serpent, Daniel was thrown into the den of lions; but being preserved through the providence of God by Ambacub, he is restored on the seventh day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:133
verses.text: At this period, too, occurred the sign of Jona; and Tobias, through the assistance of the angel Raphael, married Sarah, the demon having killed her seven first suitors; and after the marriage of Tobias, his father Tobit recovered his sight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:134
verses.text: At that time Zorobabel, having by his wisdom overcome his opponents, and obtained leave from Darius for the rebuilding of Jerusalem, returned with Esdras to his native land; and by him the redemption of the people and the revisal and restoration of the inspired oracles were effected; and the passover of deliverance celebrated, and marriage with aliens dissolved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:135
verses.text: Cyrus had, by proclamation, previously enjoined the restoration of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:136
verses.text: And his promise being accomplished in the time of Darius, the feast of the dedication was held, as also the feast of tabernacles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:137
verses.text: There were in all, taking in the duration of the captivity down to the restoration of the people, from the birth of Moses, one thousand one hundred and fifty-five years, six months, and ten days; and from the reign of David, according to some, four hundred and fifty-two;  more correctly, five hundred and seventy-two years, six months, and ten days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:138
verses.text: From the captivity at Babylon, which took place in the time of Jeremiah the prophet, was fulfilled what was spoken by Daniel the prophet as follows: "Seventy weeks are determined upon thy people, and upon thy holy city, to finish the transgression, and to seal sins, and to wipe out and make reconciliation for iniquity, and to bring in everlasting righteousness, and to seal the vision and the prophet, and to anoint the Holy of Holies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:139
verses.text: Know therefore, and understand, that from the going forth of the word commanding an answer to be given, and Jerusalem to be built, to Christ the Prince, are seven weeks and sixty-two weeks; and the street shall be again built, and the wall; and the times shall be expended.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:140
verses.text: And after the sixty-two weeks the anointing shall be overthrown, and judgment shall not be in him; and he shall destroy the city and the sanctuary along with the coming Prince.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:141
verses.text: And they shall be destroyed in a flood, and to the end of the war shall be cut off by desolations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:142
verses.text: And he shall confirm the covenant with many for one week; and in the middle of the week the sacrifice and oblation shall be taken away; and in the holy place shall be the abomination of desolations, and until the consummation of time shall the consummation be assigned for desolation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:143
verses.text: And in the midst of the week shall he make the incense of sacrifice cease, and of the wing of destruction, even till the consummation, like the destruction of the oblation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:144
verses.text: That the temple accordingly was built in seven weeks, is evident; for it is written in Esdras.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:145
verses.text: And thus Christ became King of the Jews, reigning in Jerusalem in the fulfilment of the seven weeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:146
verses.text: And in the sixty and two weeks the whole of Judaea was quiet, and without wars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:147
verses.text: And Christ our Lord, "the Holy of Holies," having come and fulfilled the vision and the prophecy, was anointed in His flesh by the Holy Spirit of His Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:148
verses.text: In those "sixty and two weeks," as the prophet said, and "in the one week," was He Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:149
verses.text: The half of the week Nero held sway, and in the holy city Jerusalem placed the abomination; and in the half of the week he was taken away, and Otho, and Galba, and Vitellius.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:150
verses.text: And Vespasian rose to the supreme power, and destroyed Jerusalem, and desolated the holy place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:151
verses.text: And that such are the facts of the case, is clear to him that is able to understand, as the prophet said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:152
verses.text: On the completion, then, of the eleventh year, in the beginning of the following, in the reign of Joachim, occurred the carrying away captive to Babylon by Nabuchodonosor the king, in the seventh year of his reign over the Assyrians, in the second year of the reign of Vaphres over the Egyptians, in the archonship of Philip at Athens, in the first year of the forty-eighth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:153
verses.text: The captivity lasted for seventy years, and ended in the second year of Darius Hystaspes, who had become king of the Persians, Assyrians, and Egyptians; in whose reign, as I said above, Haggai and Zechariah and the angel of the twelve prophesied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:154
verses.text: And the high priest was Joshua the son of Josedec.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:155
verses.text: And in the second year of the reign of Darius, who, Herodotus says, destroyed the power of the Magi, Zorobabel the son of Salathiel was despatched to raise and adorn the temple at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:156
verses.text: The times of the Persians are accordingly summed up thus: Cyrus reigned thirty years; Cambyses, nineteen; Darius, forty-six; Xerxes, twenty-six; Artaxerxes, forty-one; Darius, eight; Artaxerxes, forty-two; Ochus or Arses, three.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:157
verses.text: The sum total of the years of the Persian monarchy is two hundred and thirty-five years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:158
verses.text: Alexander of Macedon, having despatched this Darius, during this period, began to reign.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:159
verses.text: Similarly, therefore, the times of the Macedonian kings are thus computed: Alexander, eighteen years; Ptolemy the son of Lagus, forty years; Ptolemy Philadelphus, twenty-seven years; then Euergetes, five-and-twenty years; then Philopator, seventeen years; then Epiphanes, four-and-twenty years; he was succeeded by Philometer, who reigned five-and-thirty years; after him Physcon, twenty-nine years; then Lathurus, thirty-six years; then he that was surnamed Dionysus, twenty-nine years; and last Cleopatra reigned twenty-two years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:160
verses.text: And after her was the reign of the Cappadocians for eighteen days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:161
verses.text: Accordingly the period embraced by the Macedonian kings is, in all, three hundred and twelve years and eighteen days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:162
verses.text: Therefore those who prophesied in the time of Darius Hystaspes, about the second year of his reign,—Haggai, and Zechariah, and the angel of the twelve, who prophesied about the first year of the forty-eighth Olympiad,—are demonstrated to be older than Pythagoras, who is said to have lived in the sixty-second Olympiad, and than Thales, the oldest of the wise men of the Greeks, who lived about the fiftieth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:163
verses.text: Those wise men that are classed with Thales were then contemporaneous, as Andron says in the Tripos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:164
verses.text: For Heraclitus being posterior to Pythagoras, mentions him in his book.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:165
verses.text: Whence indisputably the first Olympiad, which was demonstrated to be four hundred and seven years later than the Trojan war, is found to be prior to the age of the above-mentioned prophets, together with those called the seven wise men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:166
verses.text: Accordingly it is easy to perceive that Solomon, who lived in the time of Menelaus (who was during the Trojan war), was earlier by  many years than the wise men among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:167
verses.text: And how many years Moses preceded him we showed, in what we said above.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:168
verses.text: And Alexander, surnamed Polyhistor, in his work on the Jews, has transcribed some letters of Solomon to Vaphres king of Egypt, and to the king of the Phoenicians at Tyre, and theirs to Solomon; in which it is shown that Vaphres sent eighty thousand Egyptian men to him for the building of the temple, and the other as many, along with a Tyrian artificer, the son of a Jewish mother, of the tribe of Dan, as is there written, of the name of Hyperon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:169
verses.text: Further, Onomacritus the Athenian, who is said to have been the author of the poems ascribed to Orpheus, is ascertained to have lived in the reign of the Pisistratidae, about the fiftieth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:170
verses.text: And Orpheus, who sailed with Hercules, was the pupil of Musaeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:171
verses.text: Amphion precedes the Trojan war by two generations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:172
verses.text: And Demodocus and Phemius were posterior to the capture of Troy; for they were famed for playing on the lyre, the former among the Phaeacians, and the latter among the suitors.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:173
verses.text: And the Oracles ascribed to Musaeus are said to be the production of Onomacritus, and the Crateres of Orpheus the production of Zopyrus of Heraclea, and The Descent to Hades that of Prodicus of Samos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:174
verses.text: Ion of Chios relates in the Triagmi, that Pythagoras ascribed certain works of his own to Orpheus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:175
verses.text: Epigenes, in his book respecting The Poetry attributed to Orpheus, says that The Descent to Hades and the Sacred Discourse were the production of Cecrops the Pythagorean; and the Peplus and the Physics of Brontinus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:176
verses.text: Some also make Terpander out ancient.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:177
verses.text: Hellanicus, accordingly, relates that he lived in the time of Midas: but Phanias, who places Lesches the Lesbian before Terpander, makes Terpander younger than Archilochus, and relates that Lesches contended with Arctinus, and gained the victory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:178
verses.text: Xanthus the Lydian says that he lived about the eighteenth Olympiad; as also Dionysius says that Thasus was built about the fifteenth Olympiad: so that it is clear that Archilochus was already known after the twentieth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:179
verses.text: He accordingly relates the destruction of Magnetes as having recently taken place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:180
verses.text: Simonides is assigned to the time of Archilochus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:181
verses.text: Callinus is not much older; for Archilochus refers to Magnetes as destroyed, while the latter refers to it as flourishing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:182
verses.text: Eumelus of Corinth being older, is said to have met Archias, who founded Syracuse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:183
verses.text: We were induced to mention these things, because the poets of the epic cycle are placed amongst those of most remote antiquity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:184
verses.text: Already, too, among the Greeks, many diviners are said to have made their appearance, as the Bacides, one a Boeotian, the other an Arcadian, who uttered many predictions to many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:185
verses.text: By the counsel of Amphiletus the Athenian, who showed the time for the onset, Pisistratus, too, strengthened his government.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:186
verses.text: For we may pass over in silence Cometes of Crete, Cinyras of Cyprus, Admetus the Thessalian, Aristaeas the Cyrenian, Amphiaraus the Athenian, Timoxeus the Corcyraean, Demaenetus the Phocian, Epigenes the Thespian, Nicias the Carystian, Aristo the Thessalian, Dionysius the Carthaginian, Cleophon the Corinthian, Hippo the daughter of Chiro, and Boeo, and Manto, and the host of Sibyls, the Samian, the Colophonian, the Cumaean, the Erythraean, the Pythian, the Taraxandrian, the Macetian, the Thessalian, and the Thesprotian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:187
verses.text: And Calchas again, and Mopsus, who lived during the Trojan war.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:188
verses.text: Mopsus, however, was older, having sailed along with the Argonants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:189
verses.text: And it is said that Battus the Cyrenian composed what is called the Divination of Mopsus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:190
verses.text: Dorotheus in the first Pandect relates that Mopsus was the disciple of Alcyon and Corone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:191
verses.text: And Pythagoras the Great always applied his mind to prognostication, and Abaris the Hyperborean, and Aristaeas the Proconnesian, and Epimenides the Cretan, who came to Sparta, and Zoroaster the Mede, and Empedocles of Agrigentum, and Phormion the Lacedaemonian; Polyaratus, too, of Thasus, and Empedotimus of Syracuse; and in addition to these, Socrates the Athenian in particular.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:192
verses.text: "For," he says in the Theages, "I am attended by a supernatural intimation, which has been assigned me from a child by divine appointment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:193
verses.text: This is a voice which, when it comes, prevents what I am about to do, but exhorts never".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:194
verses.text: And Execestus, the tyrant of the Phocians, wore two enchanted rings, and by the sound which they uttered one against the other determined the proper times for actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:195
verses.text: But he died, nevertheless, treacherously murdered, although warned beforehand by the sound, as Aristotle says in the Polity of the Phocians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:196
verses.text: Of those, too, who at one time lived as men among the Egyptians, but were constituted gods by human opinion, were Hermes the Theban, and Asclepius of Memphis; Tireseus and Manto, again, at Thebes, as Euripides says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:197
verses.text: Helenus, too, and Laocoön, and oenone, and Crenus in  Ilium.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:198
verses.text: For Crenus, one of the Heraclidae, is said to have been a noted prophet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:199
verses.text: Another was Jamus in Elis, from whom came the Jamidae; and Polyidus at Argos and Megara, who is mentioned by the tragedy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:200
verses.text: Why enumerate Telemus, who, being a prophet of the Cyclops, predicted to Polyphemus the events of Ulysses' wandering; or Onomacritus at Athens; or Amphiaraus, who campaigned with the seven at Thebes, and is reported to be a generation older than the capture of Troy; or Theoclymenus in Cephalonia, or Telmisus in Caria, or Galeus in Sicily?  There are others, too, besides these: Idmon, who was with the Argonauts, Phemonoe of Delphi, Mopsus the son of Apollo and Manto in Pamphylia, and Amphilochus the son of Amphiaraus in Cilicia, Alcmaeon among the Acarnanians, Anias in Delos, Aristander of Telmessus, who was along with Alexander.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:201
verses.text: Philochorus also relates in the first book of the work, On Divination, that Orpheus was a seer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:202
verses.text: And Theopompus, and Ephorus, and Timaeus, write of a seer called Orthagoras; as the Samian Pythocles in the fourth book of The Italics writes of Caius Julius Nepos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:203
verses.text: But some of these "thieves and robbers," as the Scripture says, predicted for the most part from observation and probabilities, as physicians and soothsayers judge from natural signs; and others were excited by demons, or were disturbed by waters, and fumigations, and air of a peculiar kind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:204
verses.text: But among the Hebrews the prophets were moved by the power and inspiration of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:205
verses.text: Before the law, Adam spoke prophetically in respect to the woman, and the naming of the creatures; Noah preached repentance; Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob gave many clear utterances respecting future and present things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:206
verses.text: Contemporaneous with the law, Moses and Aaron; and after these prophesied Jesus the son of Nave, Samuel, Gad, Nathan, Achias, Samaeas, Jehu, Elias, Michaeas, Abdiu, Elisaeus, Abbadonai, Amos, Esaias, Osee, Jonas, Joel, Jeremias, Sophonias the son of Buzi, Ezekiel, Urias, Ambacum, Naum, Daniel, Misael, who wrote the syllogisms, Aggai, Zacharias, and the angel among the twelve.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:207
verses.text: These are, in all, five-and-thirty prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:208
verses.text: And of women (for these too prophesied), Sara, and Rebecca, and Mariam, and Debbora, and Olda, i-e:, Huldah.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:209
verses.text: Then within the same period John prophesied till the baptism of salvation; and after the birth of Christ, Anna and Simeon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:210
verses.text: For Zacaharias, John's father, is said in the Gospels to have prophesied before his son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:211
verses.text: Let us then draw up the chronology of the Greeks from Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:212
verses.text: From the birth of Moses to the exodus of the Jews from Egypt, eighty years; and the period down to his death, other forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:213
verses.text: The exodus took place in the time of Inachus, before the wandering of Sothis, Moses having gone forth from Egypt three hundred and forty-five years before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:214
verses.text: From the rule of Moses, and from Inachus to the flood of Deucalion, I mean the second inundation, and to the conflagration of Phaethon, which events happened in the time of Crotopus, forty generations are enumerated (three generations being reckoned for a century).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:215
verses.text: From the flood to the conflagration of Ida, and the discovery of iron, and the Idaean Dactyls, are seventy-three years, according to Thrasyllus; and from the conflagration of Ida to the rape of Ganymede, sixty-five years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:216
verses.text: From this to the expedition of Perseus, when Glaucus established the Isthmian games in honour of Melicerta, fifteen years; and from the expedition of Perseus to the building of Troy, thirty-four years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:217
verses.text: From this to the voyage of the Argo, sixty-four years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:218
verses.text: From this to Theseus and the Minotaur, thirty-two years; then to the seven at Thebes, ten years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:219
verses.text: And to the Olympic contest, which Hercules instituted in honour of Pelops, three years; and to the expedition of the Amazons against Athens, and the rape of Helen by Theseus, nine years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:220
verses.text: From this to the deification of Hercules, eleven years; then to the rape of Helen by Alexander, four years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:221
verses.text: From the taking of Troy to the descent of aeneas and the founding of Lavinium, ten years; and to the government of Ascanius, eight years; and to the descent of the Heraclidae, sixty-one years; and to the Olympiad of Iphitus, three hundred and thirty-eight years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:222
verses.text: Eratosthenes thus sets down the dates: "From the capture of Troy to the descent of the Heraclidae, eighty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:223
verses.text: From this to the founding of Ionia, sixty years; and the period following to the protectorate of Lycurgus, a hundred and fifty-nine years; and to the first year of the first Olympiad, a hundred and eight years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:224
verses.text: From which Olympiad to the invasion of Xerxes, two hundred and ninety-seven years; from which to the beginning of the Peloponnesian war, forty-eight years; and to its close, and the defeat of the Athenians, twenty-seven years; and to the battle at Leuctra, thirty-four years; after which to the death of Philip, thirty-five years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:225
verses.text: And after this to the decease of Alexander, twelve years".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:226
verses.text: Again, from the first Olympiad, some say, to the  building of Rome, are comprehended twenty-four years; and after this to the expulsion of the kings, when consuls were created, about two hundred and forty-three years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:227
verses.text: And from the taking of Babylon to the death of Alexander, a hundred and eighty-six years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:228
verses.text: From this to the victory of Augustus, when Antony killed himself at Alexandria, two hundred and ninety-four years, when Augustus was made consul for the fourth time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:229
verses.text: And from this time to the games which Domitian instituted at Rome, are a hundred and fourteen years; and from the first games to the death of Commodus, a hundred and eleven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:230
verses.text: There are some that from Cecrops to Alexander of Macedon reckon a thousand eight hundred and twenty-eight years; and from Demophon, a thousand two hundred and fifty; and from the taking of Troy to the expedition of the Heraclidae, a hundred and twenty or a hundred and eighty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:231
verses.text: From this to the archonship of Evaenetus at Athens, in whose time Alexander is said to have marched into Asia, according to Phanias, are seven hundred and fifty years; according to Ephorus, seven hundred and thirty-five; according to Timaeus and Clitarchus, eight hundred and twenty; according to Eratosthenes, seven hundred and seventy-four.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:232
verses.text: As also Duris, from the taking of Troy to the march of Alexander into Asia, a thousand years; and from that to the archonship of Hegesias, in whose time Alexander died eleven years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:233
verses.text: From this date to the reign of Germanicus Claudius Caesar, three hundred and sixty-five years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:234
verses.text: From which time the years summed up to the death of Commodus are manifest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:235
verses.text: After the Grecian period, and in accordance with the dates, as computed by the barbarians, very large intervals are to be assigned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:236
verses.text: From Adam to the deluge are comprised two thousand one hundred and forty-eight years, four days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:237
verses.text: From Shem to Abraham, a thousand two hundred and fifty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:238
verses.text: From Isaac to the division of the land, six hundred and sixteen years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:239
verses.text: Then from the judges to Samuel, four hundred and sixty-three years, seven months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:240
verses.text: And after the judges there were five hundred and seventy-two years, six months, ten days of kings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:241
verses.text: After which periods, there were two hundred and thirty-five years of the Persian monarchy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:242
verses.text: Then of the Macedonian, till the death of Antony, three hundred and twelve years and eighteen days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:243
verses.text: After which time, the empire of the Romans, till the death of Commodus, lasted for two hundred and twenty-two years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:244
verses.text: Then, from the seventy years' captivity, and the restoration of the people into their own land to the captivity in the time of Vespasian, are comprised four hundred and ten years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:245
verses.text: Finally, from Vespasian to the death of Commodus, there are ascertained to be one hundred and twenty-one years, six months, and twenty-four days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:246
verses.text: Demetrius, in his book, On the Kings in Judaea, says that the tribes of Juda, Benjamin, and Levi were not taken captive by Sennacherim; but that there were from this captivity to the last, which Nabuchodonosor made out of Jerusalem, a hundred and twenty-eight years and six months; and from the time that the ten tribes were carried captive from Samaria till Ptolemy the Fourth, were five hundred and seventy-three years, nine months; and from the time that the captivity from Jerusalem took place, three hundred and thirty-eight years and three months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:247
verses.text: Philo himself set down the kings differently from Demetrius.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:248
verses.text: Besides, Eupolemus, in a similar work, says that all the years from Adam to the fifth year of Ptolemy Demetrius, who reigned twelve years in Egypt, when added, amount to five thousand a hundred and forty-nine; and from the time that Moses brought out the Jews from Egypt to the above-mentioned date, there are, in all, two thousand five hundred and eighty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:249
verses.text: And from this time till the consulship in Rome of Caius Domitian and Casian, a hundred and twenty years are computed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:250
verses.text: Euphorus and many other historians say that there are seventy-five nations and tongues, in consequence of hearing the statement made by Moses: "All the souls that sprang from Jacob, which went down into Egypt, were seventy-five".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:251
verses.text: According to the true reckoning, there appear to be seventy-two generic dialects, as our Scriptures hand down.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:252
verses.text: The rest of the vulgar tongues are formed by the blending of two, or three, or more dialects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:253
verses.text: A dialect is a mode of speech which exhibits a character peculiar to a locality, or a mode of speech which exhibits a character peculiar or common to a race.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:254
verses.text: The Greeks say, that among them are five dialects—the Attic, Ionic, Doric, aeolic, and the fifth the Common; and that the languages of the barbarians, which are innumerable, are not called dialects, but tongues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:255
verses.text: Plato attributes a dialect also to the gods, forming this conjecture mainly from dreams and oracles, and especially from demoniacs, who do not speak their own language or dialect, but that of the demons who have taken possession of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:256
verses.text: He thinks also that the irrational creatures have dialects, which those that belong to  the same genus understand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:257
verses.text: Accordingly, when an elephant falls into the mud and bellows out any other one that is at hand, on seeing what has happened, shortly turns, and brings with him a herd of elephants, and saves the one that has fallen in.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:258
verses.text: It is said also in Libya, that a scorpion, if it does not succeed in stinging a man, goes away and returns with several more; and that, hanging on one to the other like a chain they make in this way the attempt to succeed in their cunning design.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:259
verses.text: The irrational creatures do not make use of an obscure intimation, or hint their meaning by assuming a particular attitude, but, as I think, by a dialect of their own.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:260
verses.text: And some others say, that if a fish which has been taken escape by breaking the line, no fish of the same kind will be caught in the same place that day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:261
verses.text: But the first and generic barbarous dialects have terms by nature, since also men confess that prayers uttered in a barbarian tongue are more powerful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:262
verses.text: And Plato, in the Cratylus, when wishing to interpret πῦρ (fire), says that it is a barbaric term.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:263
verses.text: He testifies, accordingly, that the Phrygians use this term with a slight deviation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:264
verses.text: And nothing, in my opinion, after these details, need stand in the way of stating the periods of the Roman emperors, in order to the demonstration of the Saviour's birth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:265
verses.text: Augustus, forty-three years; Tiberius, twenty-two years; Caius, four years; Claudius, fourteen years; Nero, fourteen years; Galba, one year; Vespasian, ten years; Titus, three years; Domitian, fifteen years; Nerva, one year; Trajan, nineteen years; Adrian, twenty-one years; Antoninus, twenty-one years; likewise again, Antoninus and Commodus, thirty-two.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:266
verses.text: In all, from Augustus to Commodus, are two hundred and twenty-two years; and from Adam to the death of Commodus, five thousand seven hundred and eighty-four years, two months, twelve days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:267
verses.text: Some set down the dates of the Roman emperors thus:—  Caius Julius Caesar, three years, four months, five days; after him Augustus reigned forty-six years, four months, one day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:268
verses.text: Then Tiberius, twenty-six years, six months, nineteen days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:269
verses.text: He was succeeded by Caius Caesar, who reigned three years, ten months, eight days; and he by Claudius for thirteen years, eight months, twenty-eight days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:270
verses.text: Nero reigned thirteen years, eight months, twenty-eight days; Galba, seven months and six days; Otho, five months, one day; Vitellius, seven months, one day; Vespasian, eleven years, eleven months, twenty-two days; Titus, two years, two months; Domitian, fifteen years, eight months, five days; Nerva, one year, four months, ten days; Trajan, nineteen years, seven months, ten days; Adrian, twenty years, ten months, twenty-eight days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:271
verses.text: Antoninus, twenty-two years, three months, and seven days; Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, nineteen years, eleven days; Commodus, twelve years, nine months, fourteen days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:272
verses.text: From Julius Caesar, therefore, to the death of Commodus, are two hundred and thirty-six years, six months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:273
verses.text: And the whole from Romulus, who founded Rome, till the death of Commodus, amounts to nine hundred and fifty-three years, six months.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:274
verses.text: And our Lord was born in the twenty-eighth year, when first the census was ordered to be taken in the reign of Augustus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:275
verses.text: And to prove that this is true, it is written in the Gospel by Luke as follows: "And in the fifteenth year, in the reign of Tiberius Caesar, the word of the Lord came to John, the son of Zacharias".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:276
verses.text: And again in the same book: "And Jesus was coming to His baptism, being about thirty years old," and so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:277
verses.text: And that it was necessary for Him to preach only a year, this also is written: "He hath sent Me to proclaim the acceptable year of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:278
verses.text: This both the prophet spake, and the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:279
verses.text: Accordingly, in fifteen years of Tiberius and fifteen years of Augustus; so were completed the thirty years till the time He suffered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:280
verses.text: And from the time that He suffered till the destruction of Jerusalem are forty-two years and three months; and from the destruction of Jerusalem to the death of Commodus, a hundred and twenty-eight years, ten months, and three days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:281
verses.text: From the birth of Christ, therefore, to the death of Commodus are, in all, a hundred and ninety-four years, one month, thirteen days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:282
verses.text: And there are those who have determined not only the year of our Lord's birth, but also the day; and they say that it took place in the twenty-eighth year of Augustus, and in the twenty-fifth day of Pachon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:283
verses.text: And the followers of Basilides hold the day of his baptism as a festival, spending the night before in readings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:284
verses.text: And they say that it was the fifteenth year of Tiberius Caesar, the fifteenth day of the month Tubi; and some that it was the eleventh of the same month.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:285
verses.text: And treating of His passion, with very great accuracy, some say that it took place in the sixteenth year of Tiberius, on the twenty-fifth of Phamenoth; and others the twenty-fifth of Pharmuthi and others say that on the nineteenth of Pharmuthi the Saviour suffered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:286
verses.text: Further, others say that He was born on the twenty-fourth or twenty-fifth of Pharmuthi.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:287
verses.text: We have still to add to our chronology the  following,—I mean the days which Daniel indicates from the desolation of Jerusalem, the seven years and seven months of the reign of Vespasian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:288
verses.text: For the two years are added to the seventeen months and eighteen days of Otho, and Galba, and Vitellius; and the result is three years and six months, which is "the half of the week," as Daniel the prophet said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:289
verses.text: For he said that there were two thousand three hundred days from the time that the abomination of Nero stood in the holy city, till its destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:290
verses.text: For thus the declaration, which is subjoined, shows: "How long shall be the vision, the sacrifice taken away, the abomination of desolation, which is given, and the power and the holy place shall be trodden under foot? And he said to him, Till the evening and morning, two thousand three hundred days, and the holy place shall be taken away".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:291
verses.text: These two thousand three hundred days, then, make six years four months, during the half of which Nero held sway, and it was half a week; and for a half, Vespasian with Otho, Galba, and Vitellius reigned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:292
verses.text: And on this account Daniel says, "Blessed is he that cometh to the thousand three hundred and thirty-five days".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:293
verses.text: For up to these days was war, and after them it ceased.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:294
verses.text: And this number is demonstrated from a subsequent chapter, which is as follows: "And from the time of the change of continuation, and of the giving of the abomination of desolation, there shall be a thousand two hundred and ninety days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:295
verses.text: Blessed is he that waiteth, and cometh to the thousand three hundred and thirty-five days".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:296
verses.text: Flavius Josephus the Jew, who composed the history of the Jews, computing the periods, says that from Moses to David were five hundred and eighty-five years; from David to the second year of Vespasian, a thousand one hundred and seventy-nine; then from that to the tenth year of Antoninus, seventy-seven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:297
verses.text: So that from Moses to the tenth year of Antoninus there are, in all, two thousand one hundred and thirty-three years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:298
verses.text: Of others, counting from Inachus and Moses to the death of Commodus, some say there were three thousand one hundred and forty-two years; and others, two thousand eight hundred and thirty-one years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:299
verses.text: And in the Gospel according to Matthew, the genealogy which begins with Abraham is continued down to Mary the mother of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 1:300
verses.text: "For," it is said, "from Abraham to David are fourteen generations; and from David to the carrying away into Babylon are fourteen generations; and from the carrying away into Babylon till Christ are likewise other fourteen generations,"—three mystic intervals completed in six weeks.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 22—On the Greek Translation of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:2
verses.text: So much for the details respecting dates, as stated variously by many, and as set down by us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:3
verses.text: It is said that the Scriptures both of the law and of the prophets were translated from the dialect of the Hebrews into the Greek language in the reign of Ptolemy the son of Lagos, or, according to others, of Ptolemy surnamed Philadelphus; Demetrius Phalereus bringing to this task the greatest earnestness, and employing painstaking accuracy on the materials for the translation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:4
verses.text: For the Macedonians being still in possession of Asia, and the king being ambitious of adorning the library he had at Alexandria with all writings, desired the people of Jerusalem to translate the prophecies they possessed into the Greek dialect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:5
verses.text: And they being the subjects of the Macedonians, selected from those of highest character among them seventy elders, versed in the Scriptures, and skilled in the Greek dialect, and sent them to him with the divine books.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:6
verses.text: And each having severally translated each prophetic book, and all the translations being compared together, they agreed both in meaning and expression.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:7
verses.text: For it was the counsel of God carried out for the benefit of Grecian ears.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:8
verses.text: It was not alien to the inspiration of God, who gave the prophecy, also to produce the translation, and make it as it were Greek prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:9
verses.text: Since the Scriptures having perished in the captivity of Nabuchodonosor, Esdras the Levite, the priest, in the time of Artaxerxes king of the Persians, having become inspired in the exercise of prophecy restored again the whole of the ancient Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:10
verses.text: And Aristobulus, in his first book addressed to Philometor, writes in these words: "And Plato followed the laws given to us, and had manifestly studied all that is said in them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:11
verses.text: And before Demetrius there had been translated by another, previous to the dominion of Alexander and of the Persians, the account of the departure of our countrymen the Hebrews from Egypt, and the fame of all that happened to them, and their taking possession of the land, and the account of the whole code of laws; so that it is perfectly clear that the above-mentioned philosopher derived a great deal from this source, for he was very learned, as also Pythagoras, who transferred many things from our books to his own system of doctrines.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:12
verses.text: And Numenius, the Pythagorean philosopher, expressly writes: "For what is Plato, but Moses speaking in Attic Greek?" This Moses was a theologian and prophet, and as some say, an interpreter of sacred laws.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 2:13
verses.text: His family, his deeds, and life, are related by the Scriptures themselves, which are worthy of all credit; but have nevertheless to be stated by us also as well as we can.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 23—The Age, Birth, and Life of Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:2
verses.text: Moses, originally of a Chaldean family, was born in Egypt, his ancestors having migrated from Babylon into Egypt on account of a protracted famine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:3
verses.text: Born in the seventh generation, and having received a royal education, the following are the circumstances of his history.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:4
verses.text: The Hebrews having increased in Egypt to a great multitude, and the king of the country being afraid of insurrection in consequence of their numbers, he ordered all the female children born to the Hebrews to be reared (woman being unfit for war), but the male to be destroyed, being suspicious of stalwart youth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:5
verses.text: But the child being goodly, his parents nursed him secretly three months, natural affection being too strong for the monarch's cruelty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:6
verses.text: But at last, dreading lest they should be destroyed along with the child, they made a basket of the papyrus that grew there, put the child in it, and laid it on the banks of the marshy river.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:7
verses.text: The child's sister stood at a distance, and watched what would happen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:8
verses.text: In this emergency, the king's daughter, who for a long time had not been pregnant, and who longed for a child, came that day to the river to bathe and wash herself; and hearing the child cry, she ordered it to be brought to her; and touched with pity, sought a nurse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:9
verses.text: At that moment the child's sister ran up, and said that, if she wished, she could procure for her as nurse one of the Hebrew women who had recently had a child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:10
verses.text: And on her consenting and desiring her to do so, she brought the child's mother to be nurse for a stipulated fee, as if she had been some other person.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:11
verses.text: Thereupon the queen gave the babe the name of Moses, with etymological propriety, from his being drawn out of "the water,"—for the Egyptians call water "mou,"—in which he had been exposed to die.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:12
verses.text: For they call Moses one who "who breathed on being taken from the water".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:13
verses.text: It is clear that previously the parents gave a name to the child on his circumcision; and he was called Joachim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:14
verses.text: And he had a third name in heaven, after his ascension, as the mystics say—Melchi.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:15
verses.text: Having reached the proper age, he was taught arithmetic, geometry, poetry, harmony, and besides, medicine and music, by those that excelled in these arts among the Egyptians; and besides, the philosophy which is conveyed by symbols, which they point out in the hieroglyphical inscriptions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:16
verses.text: The rest of the usual course of instruction, Greeks taught him in Egypt as a royal child, as Philo says in his life of Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:17
verses.text: He learned, besides, the literature of the Egyptians, and the knowledge of the heavenly bodies from the Chaldeans and the Egyptians; whence in the Acts he is said "to have been instructed in all the wisdom of the Egyptians".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:18
verses.text: And Eupolemus, in his book On the Kings in Judea, says that "Moses was the first wise man, and the first that imparted grammar to the Jews, that the Phoenicians received it from the Jews, and the Greeks from the Phoenicians".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:19
verses.text: And betaking himself to their philosophy, he increased his wisdom, being ardently attached to the training received from his kindred and ancestors, till he struck and slew the Egyptian who wrongfully attacked the Hebrew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:20
verses.text: And the mystics say that he slew the Egyptian by a word only; as, certainly, Peter in the Acts is related to have slain by speech those who appropriated part of the price of the field, and lied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:21
verses.text: And so Artapanus, in his work On the Jews, relates "that Moses, being shut up in custody by Chenephres, king of the Egyptians, on account of the people demanding to be let go from Egypt, the prison being opened by night, by the interposition of God, went forth, and reaching the palace, stood before the king as he slept, and aroused him; and that the latter, struck with what had taken place, bade Moses tell him the name of the God who had sent him; and that he, bending forward, told him in his ear; and that the king on hearing it fell speechless, but being supported by Moses, revived again".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:22
verses.text: And respecting the education of Moses, we shall find a harmonious account in Ezekiel, the composer of Jewish tragedies in the drama entitled The Exodus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:23
verses.text: He thus writes in the person of Moses:—  "For, seeing our race abundantly increase, His treacherous snares King Pharaoh 'gainst us laid, And cruelly in brick-kilns some of us, And some, in toilsome works of building, plagued.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:24
verses.text: And towns and towers by toil of ill-starred men He raised.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:25
verses.text: Then to the Hebrew race proclaimed, That each male child should in deep-flowing Nile Be drowned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:26
verses.text: My mother bore and hid me then Three months (so afterwards she told).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:27
verses.text: Then took, And me adorned with fair array, and placed On the deep sedgy marsh by Nilus bank, While Miriam, my sister, watched afar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:28
verses.text: Then, with her maids, the daughter of the king, To bathe her beauty in the cleansing stream,  Came near, straight saw, and took and raised me up; And knew me for a Hebrew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:29
verses.text: Miriam My sister to the princess ran, and said, 'Is it thy pleasure, that I haste and find A nurse for thee to rear this child Among the Hebrew women?' The princess Gave assent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:30
verses.text: The maiden to her mother sped, And told, who quick appeared.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:31
verses.text: My own Dear mother took me in her arms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:32
verses.text: Then said The daughter of the king: 'Nurse me this child, And I will give thee wages.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:33
verses.text: 'And my name Moses she called, because she drew and saved Me from the waters on the river's bank.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:34
