verses.text: And when the days of childhood had flown by, My mother brought me to the palace where The princess dwelt, after disclosing all About my ancestry, and God's great gifts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:35
verses.text: In boyhood's years I royal nurture had, And in all princely exercise was trained, As if the princess's very son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:36
verses.text: But when The circling days had run their course, I left the royal palace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:37
verses.text: Then, after relating the combat between the Hebrew and the Egyptian, and the burying of the Egyptian in the sand, he says of the other contest:—  "Why strike one feebler than thyself? And he rejoined: Who made thee judge o'er us, Or ruler? Wilt thou slay me, as thou didst Him yesterday? And I in terror said, How is this known?"  Then he fled from Egypt and fed sheep, being thus trained beforehand for pastoral rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:38
verses.text: For the shepherd's life is a preparation for sovereignty in the case of him who is destined to rule over the peaceful flock of men, as the chase for those who are by nature warlike.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:39
verses.text: Thence God brought him to lead the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:40
verses.text: Then the Egyptians, oft admonished, continued unwise; and the Hebrews were spectators of the calamities that others suffered, learning in safety the power of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:41
verses.text: And when the Egyptians gave no heed to the effects of that power, through their foolish infatuation disbelieving, then, as is said, "the children knew" what was done; and the Hebrews afterwards going forth, departed carrying much spoil from the Egyptians, not for avarice, as the cavillers say, for God did not persuade them to covet what belonged to others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:42
verses.text: But, in the first place, they took wages for the services they had rendered the Egyptians all the time; and then in a way recompensed the Egyptians, by afflicting them in requital as avaricious, by the abstraction of the booty, as they had done the Hebrews by enslaving them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:43
verses.text: Whether, then, as may be alleged is done in war, they thought it proper, in the exercise of the rights of conquerors, to take away the property of their enemies, as those who have gained the day do from those who are worsted (and there was just cause of hostilities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 3:44
verses.text: The Hebrews came as suppliants to the Egyptians on account of famine; and they, reducing their guests to slavery, compelled them to serve them after the manner of captives, giving them no recompense); or as in peace, took the spoil as wages against the will of those who for a long period had given them no recompense, but rather had robbed them, it is all one.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 24—How Moses Discharged the Part of a Military Leader.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:2
verses.text: Our Moses then is a prophet, a legislator, skilled in military tactics and strategy, a politician, a philosopher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:3
verses.text: And in what sense he was a prophet, shall be by and by told, when we come to treat of prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:4
verses.text: Tactics belong to military command, and the ability to command an army is among the attributes of kingly rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:5
verses.text: Legislation, again, is also one of the functions of the kingly office, as also judicial authority.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:6
verses.text: Of the kingly office one kind is divine,—that which is according to God and His holy Son, by whom both the good things which are of the earth, and external and perfect felicity too, are supplied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:7
verses.text: "For," it is said, "seek what is great, and the little things shall be added".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:8
verses.text: And there is a second kind of royalty, inferior to that administration which is purely rational and divine, which brings to the task of government merely the high mettle of the soul; after which fashion Hercules ruled the Argives, and Alexander the Macedonians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:9
verses.text: The third kind is what aims after one thing—merely to conquer and overturn; but to turn conquest either to a good or a bad purpose, belongs not to such rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:10
verses.text: Such was the aim of the Persians in their campaign against Greece.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:11
verses.text: For, on the one hand, fondness for strife is solely the result of passion, and acquires power solely for the sake of domination; while, on the other, the love of good is characteristic of a soul which uses its high spirit for noble ends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:12
verses.text: The fourth, the worst of all, is the sovereignty which acts according to the promptings of the passions, as that of Sardanapalus, and those who propose to themselves as their end the gratification of the passions to the utmost.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:13
verses.text: But the instrument of regal sway—the instrument at once of that which overcomes by virtue, and that which does so by force—is the power of managing (or tact).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:14
verses.text: And it varies according to the nature and the material.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:15
verses.text: In the case of arms and of fighting animals the ordering power is the soul and mind, by means animate and inanimate; and in the case of the passions of the soul, which we master by virtue, reason is the ordering power, by affixing the seal of continence and self-restraint, along with holiness, and sound knowledge with truth, making the result of the whole to terminate in piety towards God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:16
verses.text: For it is wisdom which regulates  in the case of those who so practice virtue; and divine things are ordered by wisdom, and human affairs by politics—all things by the kingly faculty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:17
verses.text: He is a king, then, who governs according to the laws, and possesses the skill to sway willing subjects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:18
verses.text: Such is the Lord, who receives all who believe on Him and by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:19
verses.text: For the Father has delivered and subjected all to Christ our King, "that at the name of Jesus every knee may bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth, and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:20
verses.text: Now, generalship involves three ideas: caution, enterprise, and the union of the two.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:21
verses.text: And each of these consists of three things, acting as they do either by word, or by deeds, or by both together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:22
verses.text: And all this can be accomplished either by persuasion, or by compulsion, or by inflicting harm in the way of taking vengeance on those who ought to be punished; and this either by doing what is right, or by telling what is untrue, or by telling what is true, or by adopting any of these means conjointly at the same time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:23
verses.text: Now, the Greeks had the advantage of receiving from Moses all these, and the knowledge of how to make use of each of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:24
verses.text: And, for the sake of example, I shall cite one or two instances of leadership.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:25
verses.text: Moses, on leading the people forth, suspecting that the Egyptians would pursue, left the short and direct route, and turned to the desert, and marched mostly by night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:26
verses.text: For it was another kind of arrangement by which the Hebrews were trained in the great wilderness, and for a protracted time, to belief in the existence of one God alone, being inured by the wise discipline of endurance to which they were subjected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:27
verses.text: The strategy of Moses, therefore, shows the necessity of discerning what will be of service before the approach of dangers, and so to encounter them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:28
verses.text: It turned out precisely as he suspected, for the Egyptians pursued with horses and chariots, but were quickly destroyed by the sea breaking on them and overwhelming them with their horses and chariots, so that not a remnant of them was left.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:29
verses.text: Afterwards the pillar of fire, which accompanied them (for it went before them as a guide), conducted the Hebrews by night through an untrodden region, training and bracing them, by toils and hardships, to manliness and endurance, that after their experience of what appeared formidable difficulties, the benefits of the land, to which from the trackless desert he was conducting them, might become apparent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:30
verses.text: Furthermore, he put to flight and slew the hostile occupants of the land, falling upon them from a desert and rugged line of march (such was the excellence of his generalship).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:31
verses.text: For the taking of the land of those hostile tribes was a work of skill and strategy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:32
verses.text: Perceiving this, Miltiades, the Athenian general, who conquered the Persians in battle at Marathon, imitated it in the following fashion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:33
verses.text: Marching over a trackless desert, he led on the Athenians by night, and eluded the barbarians that were set to watch him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:34
verses.text: For Hippias, who had deserted from the Athenians, conducted the barbarians into Attica, and seized and held the points of vantage, in consequence of having a knowledge of the ground.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:35
verses.text: The task was then to elude Hippias.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:36
verses.text: Whence rightly Miltiades, traversing the desert and attacking by night the Persians commanded by Dates, led his soldiers to victory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:37
verses.text: But further, when Thrasybulus was bringing back the exiles from Phyla, and wished to elude observation, a pillar became his guide as he marched over a trackless region.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:38
verses.text: To Thrasybulus by night, the sky being moonless and stormy, a fire appeared leading the way, which, having conducted them safely, left them near Munychia, where is now the altar of the light-bringer (Phosphorus).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:39
verses.text: From such an instance, therefore, let our accounts become credible to the Greeks, namely, that it was possible for the omnipotent God to make the pillar of fire, which was their guide on their march, go before the Hebrews by night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:40
verses.text: It is said also in a certain oracle,—  "A pillar to the Thebans is joy-inspiring Bacchus,"  from the history of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:41
verses.text: Also Euripides says, in Antiope,—  "In the chambers within, the herdsman, With chaplet of ivy, pillar of the Evoean god".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:42
verses.text: The pillar indicates that God cannot be portrayed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:43
verses.text: The pillar of light, too, in addition to its pointing out that God cannot be represented, shows also the stability and the permanent duration of the Deity, and His unchangeable and inexpressible light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:44
verses.text: Before, then, the invention of the forms of images, the ancients erected pillars, and reverenced them as statues of the Deity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:45
verses.text: Accordingly, he who composed the Phoronis writes,—  "Callithoe, key-bearer of the Olympian queen: Argive Hera, who first with fillets and with fringes The queen's tall column all around adorned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:46
verses.text: Further, the author of Europia relates that the statue of Apollo at Delphi was a pillar in these words:—  "That to the god first-fruits and tithes we may On sacred pillars and on lofty column hang".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:47
verses.text: Apollo, interpreted mystically by "privation of  many," means the one God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 4:48
verses.text: Well, then, that fire like a pillar, and the fire in the desert, is the symbol of the holy light which passed through from earth and returned again to heaven, by the wood of the cross, by which also the gift of intellectual vision was bestowed on us.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 25—Plato an Imitator of Moses in Framing Laws.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:2
verses.text: Plato the philosopher, aided in legislation by the books of Moses, censured the polity of Minos, and that of Lycurgus, as having bravery alone as their aim; while he praised as more seemly the polity which expresses some one thing, and directs according to one precept.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:3
verses.text: For he says that it becomes us to philosophize with strength, and dignity, and wisdom,—holding unalterably the same opinions about the same things, with reference to the dignity of heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:4
verses.text: Accordingly, therefore, he interprets what is in the law, enjoining us to look to one God and to do justly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:5
verses.text: Of politics, he says there are two kinds,—the department of law, and that of politics, strictly so called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:6
verses.text: And he refers to the Creator, as the Statesman (ὁ πολιτικός) by way of eminence, in his book of this name (ὁ πολιτικός); and those who lead an active and just life, combined with contemplation, he calls statesmen (πολιτικοί).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:7
verses.text: That department of politics which is called "Law," he divides into administrative magnanimity and private good order, which he calls orderliness; and harmony, and sobriety, which are seen when rulers suit their subjects, and subjects are obedient to their rulers; a result which the system of Moses sedulously aims at effecting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:8
verses.text: Further, that the department of law is founded on generation, that of politics on friendship and consent, Plato, with the aid he received, affirms; and so, coupled with the laws the philosopher in the Epinomis, who knew the course of all generation, which takes place by the instrumentality of the planets; and the other philosopher, Timaeus, who was an astronomer and student of the motions of the stars, and of their sympathy and association with one another, he consequently joined to the "polity" (or "republic").

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:9
verses.text: Then, in my opinion, the end both of the statesman, and of him who lives according to the law, is contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:10
verses.text: It is necessary, therefore, that public affairs should be rightly managed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:11
verses.text: But to philosophize is best.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:12
verses.text: For he who is wise will live concentrating all his energies on knowledge, directing his life by good deeds, despising the opposite, and following the pursuits which contribute to truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:13
verses.text: And the law is not what is decided by law (for what is seen is not vision), nor every opinion (not certainly what is evil).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:14
verses.text: But law is the opinion which is good, and what is good is that which is true, and what is true is that which finds "true being," and attains to it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:15
verses.text: "He who is," says Moses, "sent me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 5:16
verses.text: In accordance with which, namely, good opinion, some have called law, right reason, which enjoins what is to be done and forbids what is not to be done.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 26—Moses Rightly Called a Divine Legislator, And, Though Inferior to Christ, Far Superior to the Great Legislators of the Greeks, Minos and Lycurgus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:2
verses.text: Whence the law was rightly said to have been given by Moses, being a rule of right and wrong; and we may call it with accuracy the divine ordinance (θεσμός), inasmuch as it was given by God through Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:3
verses.text: It accordingly conducts to the divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:4
verses.text: Paul says: "The law was instituted because of transgressions, till the seed should come, to whom the promise was made".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:5
verses.text: Then, as if in explanation of his meaning, he adds: "But before faith came, we were kept under the law, shut up," manifestly through fear, in consequence of sins, "unto the faith which should afterwards be revealed; so that the law was a schoolmaster to bring us to Christ, that we should be justified by faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:6
verses.text: The true legislator is he who assigns to each department of the soul what is suitable to it and to its operations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:7
verses.text: Now Moses, to speak comprehensively, was a living law, governed by the benign Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:8
verses.text: Accordingly, he furnished a good polity, which is the right discipline of men in social life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:9
verses.text: He also handled the administration of justice, which is that branch of knowledge which deals with the correction of transgressors in the interests of justice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:10
verses.text: Co-ordinate with it is the faculty of dealing with punishments, which is a knowledge of the due measure to be observed in punishments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:11
verses.text: And punishment, in virtue of its being so, is the correction of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:12
verses.text: In a word, the whole system of Moses is suited for the training of such as are capable of becoming good and noble men, and for hunting out men like them; and this is the art of command.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:13
verses.text: And that wisdom, which is capable of treating rightly those who have been caught by the Word, is legislative wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:14
verses.text: For it is the property of this wisdom, being most kingly, to possess and use,  It is the wise man, therefore, alone whom the philosophers proclaim king, legislator, general, just, holy, God-beloved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:15
verses.text: And if we discover these qualities in Moses, as shown from the Scriptures themselves, we may, with the most assured persuasion, pronounce Moses to be truly wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:16
verses.text: As then we say that it belongs to the  shepherd's art to care for the sheep; for so "the good shepherd giveth his life for the sheep;" so also we shall say that legislation,inasmuch as it presides over and cares for the flock of men, establishes the virtue of men, by fanning into flame, as far as it can, what good there is in humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:17
verses.text: And if the flock figuratively spoken of as belonging to the Lord is nothing but a flock of men, then He Himself is the good Shepherd and Lawgiver of the one flock, "of the sheep who hear Him," the one who cares for them, "seeking," and finding by the law and the word, "that which was lost;" since, in truth, the law is spiritual and leads to felicity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:18
verses.text: For that which has arisen through the Holy Spirit is spiritual.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:19
verses.text: And he is truly a legislator, who not only announces what is good and noble, but understands it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:20
verses.text: The law of this man who possesses knowledge is the saving precept; or rather, the law is the precept of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:21
verses.text: For the Word is "the power and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:22
verses.text: Again, the expounder of the laws is the same one by whom the law was given; the first expounder of the divine commands, who unveiled the bosom of the Father, the only-begotten Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:23
verses.text: Then those who obey the law, since they have some knowledge of Him, cannot disbelieve or be ignorant of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:24
verses.text: But those who disbelieve, and have shown a repugnance to engage in the works of the law, whoever else may, certainly confess their ignorance of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:25
verses.text: What, then, is the unbelief of the Greeks? Is it not their unwillingness to believe the truth which declares that the law was divinely given by Moses, whilst they honour Moses in their own writers? They relate that Minos received the laws from Zeus in nine years, by frequenting the cave of Zeus; and Plato, and Aristotle, and Ephorus write that Lycurgus was trained in legislation by going constantly to Apollo at Delphi.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:26
verses.text: Chamaeleo of Heraclea, in his book On Drunkenness, and Aristotle in The Polity of Locrians, mention that Zaleucus the Locrian received the laws from Athene.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 6:27
verses.text: But those who exalt the credit of Greek legislation as far as in them lies, by referring it to a divine source, after the model of Mosaic prophecy, are senseless in not owning the truth, and the archetype of what is related among them.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 27—The Law, Even in Correcting and Punishing, Aims at the Good of Men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:2
verses.text: Let no, one then, run down law, as if, on account of the penalty, it were not beautiful and good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:3
verses.text: For shall he who drives away bodily disease appear a benefactor; and shall not he who attempts to deliver the soul from iniquity, as much more appear a friend, as the soul is a more precious thing than the body? Besides, for the sake of bodily health we submit to incisions, and cauterizations, and medicinal draughts; and he who administers them is called saviour and healer, even though amputating parts, not from grudge or ill-will towards the patient, but as the principles of the art prescribe, so that the sound parts may not perish along with them, and no one accuses the physician's art of wickedness; and shall we not similarly submit, for the soul's sake, to either banishment, or punishment, or bonds, provided only from unrighteousness we shall attain to righteousness?  For the law, in its solicitude for those who obey, trains up to piety, and prescribes what is to be done, and restrains each one from sins, imposing penalties even on lesser sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:4
verses.text: But when it sees any one in such a condition as to appear incurable, posting to the last stage of wickedness, then in its solicitude for the rest, that they may not be destroyed by it (just as if amputating a part from the whole body), it condemns such an one to death, as the course most conducive to health.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:5
verses.text: "Being judged by the Lord," says the apostle, "we are chastened, that we may not be condemned with the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:6
verses.text: For the prophet had said before, "Chastening, the Lord hath chastised me, but hath not given me over unto death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:7
verses.text: "For in order to teach thee His righteousness," it is said, "He chastised thee and tried thee, and made thee to hunger and thirst in the desert land; that all His statutes and His judgments may be known in thy heart, as I command thee this day; and that thou mayest know in thine heart, that just as if a man were chastising his son, so the Lord our God shall chastise thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:8
verses.text: And to prove that example corrects, he says directly to the purpose: "A clever man, when he seeth the wicked punished, will himself be severely chastised, for the fear of the Lord is the source of wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:9
verses.text: But it is the highest and most perfect good, when one is able to lead back any one from the practice of evil to virtue and well-doing, which is the very function of the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:10
verses.text: So that, when one fails into any incurable evil,—when taken possession of, for example, by wrong or covetousness,—it will be for his good if he is put to death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:11
verses.text: For the law is beneficent, being able to make some righteous from unrighteous, if they will only give ear to it, and by releasing others from present evils; for those who have chosen  to live temperately and justly, it conducts to immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:12
verses.text: To know the law is characteristic of a good disposition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:13
verses.text: And again: "Wicked men do not understand the law; but they who seek the Lord shall have understanding in all that is good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:14
verses.text: It is essential, certainly, that the providence which manages all, be both supreme and good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:15
verses.text: For it is the power of both that dispenses salvation—the one correcting by punishment, as supreme, the other showing kindness in the exercise of beneficence, as a benefactor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:16
verses.text: It is in your power not to be a son of disobedience, but to pass from darkness to life, and lending your ear to wisdom, to be the legal slave of God, in the first instance, and then to become a faithful servant, fearing the Lord God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:17
verses.text: And if one ascend higher, he is enrolled among the sons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:18
verses.text: But when "charity covers the multitude of sins," by the consummation of the blessed hope, then may we welcome him as one who has been enriched in love, and received into the elect adoption, which is called the beloved of God, while he chants the prayer, saying, "Let the Lord be my God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:19
verses.text: The beneficent action of the law, the apostle showed in the passage relating to the Jews, writing thus: "Behold, thou art called a Jew and restest in the law, and makest thy boast in God, and knowest the will of God, and approvest the things that are more excellent, being instructed out of the law, and art confident that thou thyself art a guide of the blind, a light of them who are in darkness, an instructor of the foolish, a teacher of babes, who hast the form of knowledge and of truth in the law".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:20
verses.text: For it is admitted that such is the power of the law, although those whose conduct is not according to the law, make a false pretence, as if they lived in the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:21
verses.text: "Blessed is the man that hath found wisdom, and the mortal who has seen understanding; for out of its mouth," manifestly Wisdom's, "proceeds righteousness, and it bears law and mercy on its tongue".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:22
verses.text: For both the law and the Gospel are the energy of one Lord, who is "the power and wisdom of God;" and the terror which the law begets is merciful and in order to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:23
verses.text: "Let not alms, and faith, and truth fail thee, but hang them around thy neck".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:24
verses.text: In the same way as Paul, prophecy upbraids the people with not understanding the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:25
verses.text: "Destruction and misery are in their ways, and the way of peace have they not known".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:26
verses.text: "There is no fear of God before their eyes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:27
verses.text: "Professing themselves wise, they became fools".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:28
verses.text: "And we know that the law is good, if a man use it lawfully".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:29
verses.text: "Desiring to be teachers of the law, they understand," says the apostle, "neither what they say, nor whereof they affirm".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 7:30
verses.text: "Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 28—The Fourfold Division of the Mosaic Law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:2
verses.text: The Mosaic philosophy is accordingly divided into four parts,—into the historic, and that which is specially called the legislative, which two properly belong to an ethical treatise; and the third, that which relates to sacrifice, which belongs to physical science; and the fourth, above all, the department of theology, "vision," which Plato predicates of the truly great mysteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:3
verses.text: And this species Aristotle calls metaphysics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:4
verses.text: Dialectics, according to Plato, is, as he says in The Statesman, a science devoted to the discovery of the explanation of things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:5
verses.text: And it is to be acquired by the wise man, not for the sake of saying or doing aught of what we find among men (as the dialecticians, who occupy themselves in sophistry, do), but to be able to say and do, as far as possible, what is pleasing to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:6
verses.text: But the true dialectic, being philosophy mixed with truth, by examining things, and testing forces and powers, gradually ascends in relation to the most excellent essence of all, and essays to go beyond to the God of the universe, professing not the knowledge of mortal affairs, but the science of things divine and heavenly; in accordance with which follows a suitable course of practice with respect to words and deeds, even in human affairs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:7
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, the Scripture, in its desire to make us such dialecticians, exhorts us: "Be ye skilful money-changers" rejecting some things, but retaining what is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:8
verses.text: For this true dialectic is the science which analyses the objects of thought, and shows abstractly and by itself the individual substratum of existences, or the power of dividing things into genera, which descends to their most special properties, and presents each individual object to be contemplated simply such as it is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:9
verses.text: Wherefore it alone conducts to the true wisdom, which is the divine power which deals with the knowledge of entities as entities, which grasps what is perfect, and is freed from all passion; not without the Saviour, who withdraws, by the divine word, the gloom of ignorance  arising from evil training, which had overspread the eye of the soul, and bestows the best of gifts,—  "That we might well know or God or man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:10
verses.text: It is He who truly shows how we are to know ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:11
verses.text: It is He who reveals the Father of the universe to whom He wills, and as far as human nature can comprehend.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 8:14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:4
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "and no study hoary with time;" for we, in a kind of barbarous way, deal in homely and rugged metaphor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:8
verses.text: And he called the myths themselves "children," as if the progeny of those, wise in their own conceits among the Greeks, who had but little insight; meaning by the "hoary studies" the truth which was possessed by the barbarians, dating from the highest antiquity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:14

verses.text: (Purpose of the Stromata)  The Alexandrian Gnostics were the pestilent outgrowth of pseudo-Platonism; and nobody could comprehend their root-errors, and their branching thorns and thistles, better than Clement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:26
verses.text: His superiority in philosophy and classical culture was exhibited, therefore, in his writings, as a necessary preliminary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:27

verses.text: And we must not blame Clement for his plan of "taking the wind out of their sails," by showing that an eclectic philosophy might be made to harmonize with the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:29

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.3 9:31
